Program 3 Prevention Program Elements include:
•	Process Safety Information
•	Process Hazard Analysis
•	Operating Procedures
•	Training
•	Mechanical Integrity
•	Management of Change
•	Pre- Start Safety Review
•	Compliance Audits
•	Incident Investigation
•	Employee Participation
•	Hot Work Permit
•	Contractors

Five-Year Accident History
For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of §68.42(a), the owner or operator shall submit as part of the RMP the information required by Section §68.42(b) on each accident covered by section §68.42(a).
“The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.”
Lineage – Oxnard has had no releases in the last five years that meet the five-year accident history reporting criteria; therefore, no data is required. 

Emergency Response Program
Lineage – Oxnard has an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in place to properly prepare for emergency evacuations, to provide first aid and medical treatment, and to contact federal, state, and local officials in the event of a major release of ammonia. 
The Facility Emergency Response Program/EAP is coordinated with the local responding units, such as the local fire department or HAZMAT Team.  Furthermore, the Facility has submitted a Hazardous Material Inventory (HMI) Business Plan via the California Environmental Reporting System (CERS).    

Planned Changes To Improve Safety
Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include:
•	A Process Hazard Analysis was performed in August 2023.
•	A Hazard Assessment was performed in May 2024.
•	A Compliance audit was performed in July 2021 and a triennial audit will be performed by July 2024.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source 
Lineage has a long-standing commitment to the worker, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  It is Lineage's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  
Program 3 at Lineage – Oxnard, is a facility-run program with continuous support from the Lineage – Compliance Department that includes Process Safety Management (PSM) Compliance and Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) Compliance.   


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled
Lineage – Oxnard is located at 908 East Third (3rd) Street, Oxnard- California, which is approximately 1/2 miles south of the Pacific Coast (PCH) Highway -California State Route 1 and two (2) miles south of US Route 101. The area immediately surrounding the facility is mostly commercial, industrial, and residential area.
The regulated substance handled at the facility is anhydrous ammonia.  
The facility's primary activities revolve around large-scale public storage of food products.  All of the ammonia inventory is used as refrigerant.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
As part of the implementation of the RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Lineage – Oxnard, which also serve to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  The regulated substance is over 10,000 lbs. federal threshold for EPA RMP and OSHA PSM.   As a result, the anhydrous ammonia-covered process (ammonia refrigeration system) is subject to OSHA PSM and EPA Program
